required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Dietary Fiber on Gastrointestinal Function
clinical_study.official_title: A Double-blind, Randomized, Crossover Trial to Assess the Gastrointestinal Tolerability of a Dietary Fiber Ingredient in Healthy Men and Women

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study will be to assess the gastrointestinal effects of a dietary fiber in healthy, adult volunteers.

detailed_description.textblock: The study is a blinded, cross-over design with subjects completing three, two-week treatment periods, separated by two, two-week washouts. Volunteers will consume a dietary fiber for two of the treatment periods at two dose levels. The fiber will be added to foods and dispensed to subjects to be consumed twice a day during each treatment period. During the control period, subjects will receive the same study foods, but with no added fiber. Major outcomes will include fecal weight, and responses to questionnaires that assess fecal characteristics, bowel habits and gastrointestinal tolerability.

primary_outcome.time_frame: subjects will report weekly for 6 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Questionnaire to assess symptoms such as nausea, bloating, and flatulence

secondary_outcome.time_frame: subjects will collect fecal output for 12 days within a six-week period
secondary_outcome.description: Fecal weight and stool characteristics will be measured

arm_group.description: Dietary fiber will be added to study foods
Dietary fiber will be added to study foods
Study foods with no added fiber will be given

intervention.description: A proprietary fiber will be given to subjects

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- healthy men and women
- age 18 - 54 years
- BMI < 30 kg/m2
Exclusion Criteria:
- presence of GI or other serious diseases known to affect GI function
- recent use of antibiotics
- very high fiber intake
- use of medications known to affect GI function
- presence of allergies to study foods

facility.name: Provident Clinical Research and Consulting Inc
